data.title: Legendary classic rock guitarist feels like a fill
authors: Saleah Blancaflor | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
data.meta_description: He revealed that doesn't much have of a choice when choosing musicians that go on tour
data.text:
Pete Townshend, co-founder, guitarist and principal songwriter of The Who, says he’s feeling like less of a main band member and more of a substitute musician most days.

Townshend, 78, expressed his feelings in a recent interview with Mojo, sharing that bandmate Roger Daltrey is the one who typically chooses the musicians that go on tour with them.

“I have not chosen any of the musicians I tour with — not even (drummer) Zak (Starkey),” Townshend told the music magazine. “When Roger brings me onstage I am filling the shoes of a guy called Frank Simes, who Roger tours with solo, and who is a guitar player and musical director.”

“I am happy to do it,” Townshend added. “Someone reading this will say, ‘Stop f------ complaining, Townshend, and put a band together of people you do want to use.’ But that scares the shit out of me.”

READ MORE: Legendary classic rock star hints at farewell tour before ‘crawling off to die’

Earlier this year while promoting his rock opera “Tommy,” Townshend admitted during a New York Times interview that a final tour would would be more about finances rather than the love of performing.

“I don’t get much of a buzz from performing with the Who,” Townshend told the publication at the time. “If I’m really honest, I’ve been touring for the money. My idea of an ordinary lifestyle is pretty elevated.”

Townshend is set to release a 14-disc set titled “Live in Concert 1985-2001,” which features nine of his rare solo concerts, on July 26. Meanwhile, “Tommy” is currently on Broadway at New York’s Nederlander Theatre.
